Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Acquisition of a Delta Ray Isotope Ratio Spectrometer for Earth Science Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fischer
1664246

This Grant for Rapid Response Research (RAPID) supports acquisition of a purchase a laser cavity ring down spectrometer that the investigator has been using from the manufacturer on loan for the purpose of making rapid field measurements of the stable carbon isotopic composition and CO2 concentrations in volcanic gases at Mt Erebus volcano in Antarctica and as well as Aleutian volcanoes. The manufacturer is offering a substantial discount for purchase of the spectrometer and purchase will allow the PI to conduct field sampling using this equipment for the rapidly approaching Austral summer field season.

This award will foster research that informs our understanding of volcanic processes and hazards and thus is congruent with NSF?s mission of promoting the progress of science and advancing the national health, prosperity and welfare given the importance of understanding volcanic processes and for the training of next generation scientific workforce in modern experimental analysis techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project enabled the acquisition of a Delta Ray Infrared Isotope Spectrometer for the analyses of carbon isotopes in carbon dioxide (CO2). This bench-top instrument is quite novel and enables the analyses of carbon isotopes in a sample within only about twenty minutes without any significant sample preparations. This aspect allows for advancing research that requires high volumes of sample analyses and also the deployment of the instrument in the field area. We took advantage of these attributes for several projects:

1- analyses of volcanic gases emitted from the active and previously unsampled volcanoes of the remote Western Aleutians. This work showed that the CO2 that is being emitted from these volcanoes is to a large extent sourced from the organic sediments that are subducted below these volcanoes and into the mantle. This work has implications for better understanding the global deep carbon cycle.

2- determining the sources of CO2 in the ice caves that from on Erebus Volcano, Antarctica. Here we used the instrument which was deployed on the volcano to identify CO2 that is directly degassing from the active magma body below the volcano and distinguish it from CO2 that, prior to degassing at the surface through the caves, was dissolved in a liquid hydrothermal system below the ice. This work has implications for better understanding the degassing of CO2 from glaciated volcanoes and the potential  impact of glacier melting on the CO2 emissions from these volcanoes.

3- characterizing the CO2 that is emitted in a region of southwestern Utah that may have the potential for enhanced geothermal energy development. This work allowed us to fingerprint the CO2 sources in the region an provide critical information as to whether this area would potentially be suited for enhanced (non-magmatic) production of geothermal energy. This project is applied science and takes advantage of our gained understanding of the potential sources of CO2 in various tectonic regions as well as the ability to measure carbon isotopes on site.

4- development and testing of a new method to determine the carbon isotope composition of CO2 in volcanic and hydrothermal gas samples. We used the Delta Ray instrument to develop techniques that allow us to rapidly analyze the carbon isotope composition of CO2 from volcanic gas samples. This work enhanced our laboratory capabilities and allows us to process more samples in shorter amounts of time.

Overall, the instrument is a great asset for our work and is used extensively in the field and in the laboratory. The performed work spans basic science research as well as applied research in fields of geothermal energy exploration and volcanic activity forecasting.
